title: German contractions! Yays!
content:
Do you know why Hitler lost the war?

Because German doesn't have a single contraction, thats why.

Look, I used one just then! Thats, that is! See? Now what I think German needs is:

Es't = Es ist [its]
Das't = Das ist [Thats]
Kann'cht = Kann nicht [Can't]
War'cht = War nicht [wasn't]
Waren'cht = Waren nicht [weren't]
IMKM = In Meiner Keen Meinung [IMKO]
hll = Heraus loud lachen [lol]
hllz [lolz]

You get the idea. Anyone think of any more to add?

Does anyone know any good contractions for I'll, they'll, we'll etc? German is more complex when using 'will'

A proud member of the signature stealing society

[img]http://img.photobucket.com/albums/v410/Gannalev/Mod2.jpg[/img]

"No one should be here."
-Levellord

title: Intriguing.
content:
Noo! There is something classy about that little quirk. I was not aware of it until now, but it would explain why I like the sound of the language so much [and likewise Ye Olde English, though it likely is not as devoid of such things as German].

Hmm... now that I think about it, it could be any fragment of speech spoken long-windedly as such, rather than a particular language, that has that effect.Cave assectatorem Ductoris Alacris

The development of the hardware, and the greater ability to express every idea that flies into a programmers head, mean that game creators have made the new games congested with every technique in their power. The basic games behind all this are so blurred that people cant catch up. We should go back to basics like Pac-Man and play in an easier, more relaxed way. -Toru Iwatani

[url=http://jimsoft.spatang.com/]JimSoft Lair[/url]

title: IMKM
content: That's cool LL! [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-smile.gif[/img] That 't and 'sch would be useful. Clever! [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-dexter.gif[/img] Eat your veggies!

title: Re: German contractions! Yays!
content:
There are contractions, for example:

Was is'n das? = Was ist denn das?
Mach's! = Mache es!
Dann woll'n wir mal! = Dann wollen wir mal!

- We want "The Universe is Toast" ! - [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-yorp.gif[/img]

title: Ehem...
content:
As you notice; she is part of the signature stealing sociaty; she stole my signature!!!

Hehehe...

BTW - You were joking about Hitler... right?

-- NAJAWA --

title: Re: Ehem...
content:
No, Hitler was both misunderstood, and not nearly as evil as he is made out to be.

Was it Hitler who walked past thousands of starving and dying prisioners each day? Was it Hitler who threw the corpses into the ovens, or set fire to live people? Was it Hitler who shot people just because he felt like it? Performed operations without anasthetic?

Hitler was just an ordinary a$$hole who got in charge, The true evil were those who did the work, manned the camps, and peopled the towns. Most of them would have seen the end of the war and remained unpunished. One of the sadder facts of life.

I didn't know there were German contractions. They never teach you them in books, thats the problem, if Hitler had put out books teaching German contractions he'd have won the war.

(By the way, I don't mean with 'you' anyone in particular.)Eat your veggies!

title: Re: Ehem...
content:
No, babelfish is actually the real article. The problem lies in the fact that a lot of the mental telepathy is lost when its typed, copied, sent along telephone wires and so on.

See: [url=http://www.tashian.com/multibabel/]www.tashian.com/multibabel/[/url]


Let us put a verse of Rammstein through it shall we?

Wir teilen Zimmer und das Bett
Brderlein komm und sei so nett
Brderlein komm fass mich an
rutsch ganz dicht an mich heran

Becomes:

We divide rooms and the bed.
Brother flax come and is so nice.
Brother flax arrives barrel me.
Slide completely closely to me near.

When, as far as I can tell, it is actually:

We share a room and bed,
Brother dearest, come and be so kind,
Brother dearest, come touch me
Slide up close to me.

Its pretty easy to see where it messes up.


[quote]Quote:[hr]Sie mgen Kse?=Do you like cheese?[hr][/quote]

That was the first German sentance I ever learned, the first German word was Kse, which I mistakenly said 'kayter'
